name: Joram

talks.abstract: Activiti version 6 is the next evolution of the Activiti engine, applying all we have learned in the past five years and making the most awesome BPM engine even more awesome. In this session, we'll show and demonstrate all the new cool features and capabilities of Activiti.

name: Martin
summary: Alfresco Hobbyist and Activist, Founder- and Board- member of The Order Of The Bee

talks.title: Honeycomb and Beyond
talks.abstract: As part of the efforts of The Order of The Bee, we decided to create our own distribution of Alfresco, named Honeycomb. To help standardise the build, Daren Firminger and Martin Cosgrave developed a puppet-based installer system which became the first iteration of the Honeycomb distribution.  We'll talk about the choices we made during the development process, some of the difficulties encountered as well as some of the benefits of the approach. Then we'll turn our attention to Docker, a lightweight containerisation system that can bring other benefits to Honeycomb, such as being the jumping off point for developing a high-availability solution for Community Alfresco

name: Andrew
summary:
Andrew works at CERN the European Organization for Nuclear Research based in Geneva Switzerland. Andrew started working with Alfresco over 1 year ago and since then has implemented document and records management at CERNs Records Office and is continuing to roll this success out to many more services at CERN.

https://about.me/andrew.short

talks.title: Accelerating records management at CERN
talks.abstract: The Records Office at CERN keeps detailed records on each member of personnel, going as far back as the mid 1950â€™s. There are currently 230 individual document types identified covering everything from cradle to grave. Many of these documents are highly confidential and allow only a few services access, but all documents have some access restriction in place, requiring advanced access control to each document. Here Andrew will present a case study and over view of CERN and its implementation of Alfresco.

talks.title: Welcome to the jungle - Tips for Alfresco on Amazon Web Services
talks.abstract: Many people are familiar with spinning up a small Alfresco instance on a virtual machine, but taking a large-scale, content-centric organisation to the cloud is in a different league altogether.  During this session you can learn lessons from a major programme of work that had to overcome significant technical hurdles, some of which have resulted in changes to Alfresco modules. You will find out how best to:  * migrate terabytes of content from on-prem to the cloud   * adhere to security compliance with encryption at rest * choose infrastructure options to support rich media production.

In addition to frequent appearances at Alfresco events, Jeff has spoken at conferences such as JBoss World, KMWorld, ApacheCon, OSCON, JavaONE, and Devoxx.

talks.title: Would the commercial open source software you depend on survive a zombie apocalypse?
talks.abstract: Earlier this year I wrote a blog post entitled, 'Would the commercial open source software you depend on survive a zombie apocalypse?' [1]. The post asks whether or not a piece of commercial open source software would survive if the commercial company behind it ceased to exist.  Zombies aren't real, of course, but companies fold, get acquired, or lose interest in their community. What is the risk of that happening to Alfresco Software, Inc., and what does it mean to our community?  In this session I will argue that mitigating this risk is the single most important reason for this organization to exist. I hope to convince you of that, and, in so doing, motivate you to contribute and perhaps bring focus to the organization's activities.  [1] http://ecmarchitect.com/archives/2016/01/04/4054

talks.title: Have you test your backup?
talks.abstract: If you are running Alfresco in production, you most probably take backups of your system on a regular basis. But how often do you test your backups? How do you test them? In this presentation we describe our strategy at CIRB-CIBG with regular and automated recovery tests, so that we identify as quickly as possible if something is going wrong with our backups. We are interested in knowing what is other people's strategy and share ideas and experiences.

name: Gianni

the talk).

My profile suits this topic in view of my experience as a speaker in several PostgreSQL conferences, in Europa and USA, with talks that covered general overviews as well as specific topics.

I always enjoy to take questions from the audience and discuss specific points in more detail, either during the talk or after.

talks.title: PostgreSQL: what you should know to improve your Alfresco
talks.abstract: The default installation of Alfresco includes a basic installation of PostgreSQL, which already works well for several scenarios. But you can do much better with PostgreSQL, improving the performance of Alfresco, and making things easier to maintain.  In this presentation you will see how to design a robust solution for a highly-available database; how to take your backups and do auditing analysis without impacting production performance; how to recover Alfresco's database just before the point of a critical user mistake, instead of back to your nightly snapshot.  If you feel (or someone told you) that PostgreSQL is hard to administrate, we will show you why PostgreSQL is actually DBA-friendly. It has excellent documentation and a great community ready to help. In this presentation you will understand how this forever free database will help you to improve your Alfresco.

talks.title: Multiple Share-based applications on the same back-end Alfresco repository: pitfalls and best practices
talks.abstract: Organizations often wish to use Alfresco as the back-end repository for a number of diverse business applications. However straightforward this requirement, the technical implementation is often a challenge since these applications all require specific front-end customisations. When deploying multiple customized Share front-end for these business applications, some aspects such as workflows, dashboards, etc. cannot be easily separated.  One option is building your front-end applications from scratch, but that ignores the wealth of functionality that is available in Share out-of-the-box. Moreover some organizations already use Share as a front-end and would like to keep a consistent experience for their users.  In this talk we share our experience on using multiple customized Share instances as business application front-end on the same Alfresco repository. Some potential pitfalls when developing such solutions are:  * The use of specific personal dashboards for each application, which conflicts with the current single dashboard configuration within Alfresco  * The definition of application-specific workflows, which conflicts with Shareâ€™s default behavior of showing all defined workflows  * Out-of-the-box dashlets whose queries are not limited to your application scope.  * â€¦  This talk will give an overview of some of the more dangerous pitfalls we encountered, how we solved them and what best practices to keep in mind.

talks.title: Gotchas encountered while implementing an asynchronous transformation service for Alfresco

To reduce the load generated by these transformations a solution called 'ecm4u Alfresco SmartTransformer' was implemented that performs the transformation asynchronously in a separate process. It was surprisingly difficult to make this approach work with Alfresco. This talk briefly describes the implemented solution and especially gives details for the various problems encountered while fitting an asynchronous transformation into Alfresco.

talks.title: Externalizing the permission service in a Business Rules Engine
talks.abstract: Extending the permission service in Alfresco is never an easy task and should be done with extreme cautiousness. In many cases the extension points provided by Alfresco such as rules and dynamic authorities are sufficient. For instance, the need to have permissions that dependent on meta-data.  But then if you have hundreds of rules which set permissions at the node-level it will be difficult to maintain all of this.  Also, in an enterprise environment Alfresco is probably not the only application developed. You might already have business rules and business data in place. You obviously want to re-use the existing and even centralize it. These are some of the reasons which led us in a direction of externalizing the permission system in a Business Rules Engine. Our instance of Alfresco Community now calls the rules-engine to ask whether or not a person has a permission on a document. Behind the scene this could trigger a complex logic involving business data which might even not be stored in Alfresco.

talks.title: Backing data silo attack: Alfresco sharding, SOLR for non-flat objects
talks.abstract: Building a single content platform for few dozens quite loaded applications is a complex task. It becomes even worse, if application developers are not sure about expected load and content structure in the next few years. This talk concentrates on two aspects of this challenge.  * Clustering and sharding - different solutions for different problems. Sharding Alfresco - reasons and implementation. Building federation proxy to aggregate multiple independent Alfresco repositories and provide a single API entry point on top of them. Live technical experience only - issues, solutions, limitations, lessons learned. Live benchmark data included.  * Handling complex search queries on top of sharded installation. A lot of search use cases are not covered with out of the box flat SOLR indexing. Sometimes users need to search complex nested objects, not just files. (It's more or less about indexing associations - 'I'd like to find all cases (node A), created by the company (node B) with name matching this, and containing child documents (nodes C) registered not later than that date' - it's quite hard to match this query having only nodes properties in the index.) We implemented an external SOLR Cloud integrated with sharded Alfresco installation to serve such complex search requests using custom indexing logic based on SOLR nested objects. In this talk we will cover reasons for such custom indexing architecture, and share an experience of its implementation.  Bonuses: * Short live demo - Share UI on top of sharded Alfresco * Call for community participation - let's turn this experience into open source project

talks.title: 2 years of Aikau - how is it faring and what do we want from it?
talks.abstract: After a time of development without a public name, the Aikau framework was introduced to the Alfresco community in Feburary of 2014. Since then there have been two product releases of the Alfresco ECM product and more than 70 incremental releases of the Aikau framework. In addition to new features of the core product, various official and community addons now use the framework to enhance or customize the Share application. This talk aims to give an external point-of-view on how the Aikau framework helps users tackle their business requirements in developing both basic customisations to existing functionality and complex, custom business applications. It will look at a sub-set of use cases that are supported by or that members of the community have implemented on top of Aikau, and review the advantages and potential short-comings of the framework in that context. Additionally, the talk will try to summarize community concerns and expectations regarding the future of Aikau, and how the community can work together to make those expectations a reality.

talks.title: Creating your custom analytics with AAAR
talks.abstract: The analytics in Alfresco represent an emerging interest for the users and the integration with Pentaho is the leading solution on both the Community and Enterprise Editions. AAAR is beyond the 4-th version and has bundled reports, dashboards and free analysis on audit data, repository and workflows. But in most cases, the bundled analytics should be customized to cover the business needs. In this talk is shown how to develop a customized set of analytics starting simply from some business questions. All of this to create your own Business Intelligence solution over one or more Alfresco instances.

talks.title: Alfresco SDK - Past, Present and The Future
talks.abstract: The Alfresco SDK have had a rough life, starting out as a community contribution, finally being picked up by Alfresco and treated as part of the product.   With that being said, the Alfresco SDK has not always been easy to work with. Upgrades have been difficult and it can be tricky to understand and get the most out of the setup.  In this session you will hear about where we are today, how we got there and finally how we can learn from history to create a brand new SDK that will empower all Alfresco developers.

name: Alexey
summary: ITD Systems lead developer, his presentation at Alfresco DevCon 2011 - http://www.slideshare.net/oksanakurysheva/alfresco-devcon-2011-implementing-egov-portal-powered-by-alfresco-and-orbeon

talks.title: Backing data silo attack: Alfresco sharding, SOLR for non-flat objects
talks.abstract: Building a single content platform for few dozens quite loaded applications is a complex task. It becomes even worse, if application developers are not sure about expected load and content structure in the next few years. This talk concentrates on two aspects of this challenge.  * Clustering and sharding - different solutions for different problems. Sharding Alfresco - reasons and implementation. Building federation proxy to aggregate multiple independent Alfresco repositories and provide a single API entry point on top of them. Live technical experience only - issues, solutions, limitations, lessons learned. Live benchmark data included.  * Handling complex search queries on top of sharded installation. A lot of search use cases are not covered with out of the box flat SOLR indexing. Sometimes users need to search complex nested objects, not just files. (It's more or less about indexing associations - 'I'd like to find all cases (node A), created by the company (node B) with name matching this, and containing child documents (nodes C) registered not later than that date' - it's quite hard to match this query having only nodes properties in the index.) We implemented an external SOLR Cloud integrated with sharded Alfresco installation to serve such complex search requests using custom indexing logic based on SOLR nested objects. In this talk we will cover reasons for such custom indexing architecture, and share an experience of its implementation.  Bonuses: * Short live demo - Share UI on top of sharded Alfresco * Call for community participation - let's turn this experience into open source project
